questions.text: A 59-year-old man presents to the clinic for an annual well-patient visit. He has no specific concerns but reports on review of symptoms occasional daytime fatigue. His wife mentions that the patient snores frequently. Past medical history is notable for hypertension and class II obesity. He drinks 1-2 beers nightly. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), blood pressure is 138/88 mm Hg, heart rate is 92 beats per minute, respiratory rate is 12 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. BMI is 38 kg/m2. Cardiac auscultation reveals an irregular rhythm. Bilaterally Lungs are clear to auscultation. There is no peripheral edema. On ECG an irregular rhythm is seen, P Waves are absent, and the heart rate is 92 beats per minute. Which of the following is most likely associated with this patient’s cardiac arrhythmia?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with an irregularly irregular heart rate and ECG findings consistent with atrial fibrillation (AF). He has several risk factors for obstructive sleep apnea (OSA), including obesity and hypertension, and he has findings consistent with obstructive sleep apnea including snoring and daytime fatigue. OSA can increase the risk of atrial fibrillation due to intermittent hypoxia and increased sympathetic activity.        

In a patient with AF, history may reveal symptoms such as palpitations, dizziness, shortness of breath, and fatigue. Patients may also report chest discomfort or lightheadedness, in some cases, symptoms may be intermittent, especially with paroxysmal AF. The primary risk factors for AF include hypertension, obesity, OSA, cardiomyopathy, diabetes, and hyperthyroidism. Physical examination can reveal an irregularly irregular pulse, which reflects the characteristic disorganized atrial activity and varying ventricular response. Blood pressure is typically normal, though it may be low in cases of unstable AF. The ventricular rate may be elevated.   

Option Analysis

❌ Chronic liver disease:
Incorrect: Chronic liver disease can be linked with various systemic findings, including jaundice and coagulopathy. However, it is not commonly associated with atrial fibrillation and there is no clinical evidence in this vignette to suggest liver dysfunction. This patient most likely has underlying sleep apnea which is associated with atrial fibrillation. 
✅ Obstructive sleep apnea:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Pulmonary fibrosis:
Incorrect: Pulmonary fibrosis is associated with restrictive lung disease and chronic hypoxia but is not commonly associated with atrial fibrillation]. Additionally, this patient does not have\ crackles on pulmonary exam. This patient most likely has underlying sleep apnea which is associated with atrial fibrillation. 
❌ Left ventricular aneurysm:
Incorrect: A left ventricular aneurysm typically follows a myocardial infarction, and patients present with signs of heart failure and persistent ST-segment elevation on ECG none of which are present in this patient. 
❌ Chronic kidney disease:
Incorrect: Chronic kidney disease can increase the risk of cardiovascular complications but is not directly linked to the development of atrial fibrillation. This patient most likely has underlying sleep apnea which is associated with atrial fibrillation.

questions.text:
A 66-year-old woman undergoes a cardiac ablation for treatment of symptomatic atrial fibrillation. Several weeks postoperatively, the patient reports shortness of breath with exertion and difficulty initiating a deep breath. She additionally reports a morning headache as well as daytime fatigue. She has not noted any voice changes. Past medical history includes hypertension and hyperlipidemia. Vitals are within normal limits. Diminished breath sounds are noted over the right lung. No cardiac murmurs are appreciated. A chest radiograph is obtained, as demonstrated below. Which of the following structures was most likely injured intraoperatively?  



Reproduced from: Radiopaedia
questions.solution:
This patient presents with symptoms and X-rays findings suggestive of injury to the phrenic nerve following a cardiac ablation procedure. Cardiac ablation is a standard procedure that uses radiofrequency or cryothermal energy to manage supraventricular arrhythmias non-pharmacologically.  

While this procedure is considered low risk, several structures are at risk of injury, including the phrenic nerve, right heart structures, and vascular access sites. Injury to the phrenic nerve results in ipsilateral paralysis of the diaphragm, which can be visualized on chest X-ray as elevation of the hemidiaphragm on the affected side.  Patients with a paralyzed hemidiaphragm can present with symptoms of exertional dyspnea, recurrent pneumonia, anxiety, insomnia, morning headache, excessive daytime somnolence, orthopnea, fatigue, or difficulty weaning from mechanical ventilation.  

 

Option Analysis

✅ Phrenic nerve :
Correct: See Main Explanation.   
❌ Recurrent laryngeal nerve:
Incorrect: Injury to the recurrent laryngeal nerve does not commonly occur with cardiac ablation procedures. Moreover, unilateral injury to the recurrent laryngeal nerve would manifest with hoarseness.
❌ Radial artery:
Incorrect: Vascular injury would manifest with evidence of hematoma, swelling, or diminished pulses over the access site. This patient’s chest x-ray suggests injury to a different structure. 
❌ Pulmonary vein :
Incorrect: Injury to the pulmonary vein can occur following cardiac ablation procedures. This patient’s chest x-ray suggests injury to the phrenic nerve, which can result in pulmonary vein stenosis and subsequent pulmonary hypertension. 
❌ Tricuspid valve:
Incorrect: Direct cardiac damage following cardiac ablation can occur, including injury to the tricuspid valve. However, injury to this structure would manifest with a systolic murmur, which is absent in this patient.

questions.text: A 57-year-old woman presents to the cardiologist for evaluation of persistent atrial fibrillation. The patient had four emergency department visits for recurrent atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response in the past month. Without relief, the patient has tried several rate-controlling medications, including metoprolol and diltiazem. The patient and cardiologist discuss further treatment options and agree to proceed with cardiac catheter ablation.  Performance of this procedure requires access through which of the following blood vessels?
questions.solution:
This patient presents for treatment of atrial fibrillation refractory to medical therapy and elects to undergo cardiac catheter ablation. In this procedure, the venous system, specifically the femoral vein, serves as the site of access to the heart.  

Venous cardiac catheterization refers to a procedure in which a catheter is inserted through the femoral vein, up the inferior vena cava, and into the right atrium. Once inside the heart's chambers, the catheter can detect arrhythmogenic foci or take measurements such as intracardiac or pulmonary pressures. In addition, the catheter may also be threaded through a patent foramen ovale or trans-septally into the left atrium and used to perform ablation procedures, in which radiofrequency or cryothermal energy is applied to areas of arrhythmogenicity in the heart to manage supraventricular arrhythmias.    



Option Analysis

✅ Femoral vein:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Femoral artery:
Incorrect: The arterial system is used for percutaneous access to the coronary arteries. However, when accessing the right side of the heart for an ablation, a catheter is introduced into the femoral vein.
❌ Radial artery:
Incorrect: The radial artery is a reasonable choice of access for percutaneous coronary intervention; however, this patient is undergoing a cardiac ablation for atrial fibrillation, and therefore venous access is necessary.
❌ Internal thoracic artery :
Incorrect: The internal thoracic artery is not a commonly used site for cardiac catheterization and ablation.
❌ Carotid artery:
Incorrect: The carotid artery is not used as an access site for cardiac ablation as there is a high risk of intraprocedural injury resulting in a stroke.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man presents to the emergency department with chest pain. The patient describes the pain as a crushing sensation in the middle of his chest that radiates to the jaw. The pain started two hours ago while he was watching television. He has a history of hypertension and diabetes mellitus, but his insurance has lapsed so he does not currently take medication for either condition. The patient has smoked a pack of cigarettes daily for the last 20 years. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), blood pressure is 90/70 mmHg, pulse is 120 bpm, and respirations are 22/minute. Oxygen saturation is 96%. The patient appears anxious and in distress. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in the acute management of this patient?

choices.text: Prepare the patient for cardiac catheterization

questions.solution:
This patient presents with symptoms consistent with acute coronary syndrome. Acute coronary syndrome (ACS) is an emergency that requires immediate care and prompt diagnostic evaluation to determine the cause and appropriate treatment. However, because of the rapidly progressive nature of the disease, any patient with a suspicion for acute coronary syndrome should be managed acutely prior to diagnostic evaluation.    

Acute management of patients with ACS starts with assessing the stability of the patient (ABCDE criteria). Patients who are unstable (e.g. hypotension) should be immediately stabilized and then assessed for the possible cause.    

For patients who are unstable (like this patient), acute management begins with obtaining intravenous access; monitoring blood pressure, heart rhythm and oxygen levels; and providing oxygen supplementation if needed.    

After the acute management of ACS is complete, evaluation to obtain an accurate diagnosis should begin immediately, which involves a focused history and physical examination, prompt 12-lead ECG, and cardiac troponin assessment.




Option Analysis

✅ Obtain intravenous access:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Provide supplemental oxygen :
Incorrect: Although oxygen monitoring and supplementation if needed are part of the acute management of acute coronary syndrome, this patient does not need oxygen supplementation as his oxygen saturation is above 95%.  
❌ Obtain a twelve-lead ECG:
Incorrect: Twelve-lead ECG should be obtained after the acute management of this unstable patient, which involves obtaining IV access, monitoring heart rhythm and blood pressure, and providing supplemental oxygen if needed.  
❌ Assess cardiac troponins :
Incorrect: Assessing cardiac troponins is part of the diagnostic evaluation of patients with acute coronary syndrome. However, acute management should precede diagnostic evaluations.  
❌ Prepare the patient for cardiac catheterization :
Incorrect: Catheterization is performed after the diagnosis acute ST-elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI) is made based on elevated cardiac enzymes and ST-segment elevation on ECG. This patient needs acute management before proceeding with the diagnostic evaluation.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man is being treated in the cardiac intensive care unit after he developed an acute ST-elevation myocardial infarction 4 days ago. The patient presented a few hours after symptom onset and was treated with medical therapy and reperfusion using percutaneous intervention to remove a clot in the left anterior descending artery. This morning, the patient developed sudden onset, severe chest pain. Evaluation at the bedside reveals a blood pressure of 60/40 mmHg. Physical examination is significant for distant heart sounds. Which of the following complications is this patient experiencing?
questions.solution:
This patient experienced an acute ST-elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI) involving the left anterior descending artery. Four day later, he is experiencing sudden, severe chest pain, hypotension, and distant heart sounds, which are characteristic of cardiac tamponade secondary to left ventricular free wall rupture.    

Left ventricular free wall rupture is a severe and lethal mechanical complication of STEMI involving the left anterior descending artery. It is most likely to occur within the first 5 days post-MI but can occur up to 2 weeks later. The patient initially develops severe chest pain due to the tearing of the left ventricular wall, followed by very rapid accumulation of blood in the pericardium, resulting in acute cardiac tamponade characterized by hypotension and distant heart sounds. Most patients enter into cardiac arrest, and thus the mortality rate for left ventricular free wall rupture is very high.    

Mechanical complications of myocardial infarction are summarized in the table below.  Other complications that occur after myocardial infarction (MI) include ventricular arrhythmias (the most common cause of the death 24 hours post-MI), postinfarction acute pericarditis (occurs within 1-3 days), Dressler syndrome (weeks to months after MI), and left ventricular aneurysm (occurs several months after MI).  


Option Analysis

✅ Left ventricular free wall rupture :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Interventricular septum rupture :
Incorrect: Interventricular septum rupture is another possible complication of STEMI involving the left anterior descending artery; however, a holosystolic murmur is heard on exam in these patients. Distant heart sounds instead indicate cardiac tamponade, which is seen in free wall rupture.  
❌ Papillary muscle rupture :
Incorrect: Papillary muscle rupture is a possible complication of STEMI involving the right coronary artery or the posterior descending artery, not the left anterior descending artery. In addition, examination shows a holosystolic murmur indicative of aortic regurgitation, not distant heart sounds.  
❌ Dressler syndrome :
Incorrect: Dressler syndrome is an autoimmune complication of STEMI and involves autoimmune attack on the pericardium leading to fibrinous pericarditis. It occurs weeks to months after the episode of STEMI, not within 4 days.  
❌ Acute postinfarction fibrinous pericarditis:
Incorrect: Acute postinfarction fibrinous pericarditis occurs 1-3 days after STEMI and is characterized by chest pain and pericardial friction rub. Hypotension and distant heart sounds are not seen.

questions.text: A 58-year-old man presents to the emergency department complaining of chest pain that started 3 hours ago and was associated with shortness of breath. The patient has a history of hyperlipidemia and diabetes, and he has smoked a pack of cigarettes daily for 40 years. The patient’s temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), blood pressure is 140/90 mmHg, pulse is 110 bpm, and respirations are 25/minute. On physical examination, the patient appears anxious and diaphoretic. Which of the following features in the history and physical examination would suggest acute coronary syndrome?

choices.text: Sharp chest pain that decreases with leaning forward
Pressure-like chest pain that radiates to the left shoulder
Sharp chest pain that is reproduced by palpation
Tearing chest pain that radiates to the back

questions.solution:
Acute coronary syndrome (ACS) is an emergency condition that requires immediate management. A precise and focused history and physical examination is critical in patients with suspected ACS as it helps rule out other differential diagnoses and can also indicate the severity of the condition.  

The most common presenting symptom of acute coronary syndrome is chest pain. The pain is usually localized to the substernal region and described as pressure-like or crushing in nature, with radiation to the jaw, left shoulder, or both. Pain can sometimes be in the epigastric region rather than the chest. Sharp, stabbing chest pain that is affected by movement or palpation is non-ischemic and suggests an alternative diagnosis. Other common symptoms of acute coronary syndrome include nausea and vomiting, dyspnea, lightheadedness, and fatigue.  

Acute coronary syndrome does not have many consistent, characteristic physical exam findings, but a detailed physical exam is important in considering all possible differential diagnoses for patients presenting with chest pain. For example, pain that is reproducible with palpation or movement during the physical examination is more suggestive of non-ischemic conditions, such as costochondritis or pericarditis.  

Most commonly, patients with ACS usually appear anxious and diaphoretic. Third and/or fourth heart sounds can sometimes be heard on auscultation in cases of ACS. While it can be physiologic, a pathologic S3 is most commonly caused by ventricular dysfunction and is predictive of adverse cardiac outcomes. The pathologic fourth heart sound (S4) is generated by forceful atrial contraction in the setting of decreased ventricular compliance as a result of conditions such as ischemic heart disease, diastolic dysfunction or hypertrophic cardiomyopathy. If congestive heart failure develops as a result of acute coronary syndrome, bibasilar crackles and hypotension can be present as well.
 

Option Analysis

❌ Sharp chest pain that decreases with leaning forward:
Incorrect: Sharp chest pain that decreases with leaning forward is a feature of acute pericarditis. The chest pain characteristic of acute coronary syndrome is not affected by movement or palpation.  
✅ Pressure-like chest pain that radiates to the left shoulder :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Sharp chest pain that is reproduced by palpation  :
Incorrect: Sharp chest pain that is reproducible by palpation is a feature of costochondritis. Overall, chest pain that is affected by palpation is suggestive of a non-ischemic cause, while the chest pain characteristic of acute coronary syndrome is not affected by movement or palpation.  
❌ Muffled heart sounds  :
Incorrect: Muffled heart sounds are a sign of cardiac tamponade, which also presents with hypotension and distended neck veins. Muffled heart sounds are not seen in patients with isolated acute coronary syndrome.  
❌ Tearing chest pain that radiates to the back :
Incorrect: Aortic dissection presents with sudden, tearing chest pain that more often radiates to the back. The quality of the pain associated with acute coronary syndrome is more commonly pressure-like and radiates to the left shoulder and/or jaw.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man is brought to the emergency department with severe, substernal chest pain. The pain started 3 hours ago with the sensation of pressure in his chest, and it has been increasing in severity. He had a few similar episodes in the past couple of days, but the pain resolved on its own. The patient’s temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), blood pressure is 80/40 mmHg, pulse is 60/minute, and respirations are 25/minute. The patient appears in distress and diaphoretic. Physical examination is otherwise unremarkable. An intravenous line is obtained, and normal saline is administered. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient?

choices.text: Immediate admission of the patient for catheterization

questions.solution:
This patient is most likely experiencing acute coronary syndrome (ACS). ACS is an emergency that is time sensitive, and thus prompt diagnosis and treatment are essential to prevent complications and improve mortality. After initial stabilization of the patient, a focused history and physical examination should be performed, followed by prompt diagnostic workup.  

The diagnostic workup for ACS begins with obtaining a 12-lead ECG and cardiac enzymes (i.e. cardiac troponins). These tests help to confirm the diagnosis and differentiate between the subtypes of ACS, which include ST-elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI), non-ST-elevation myocardial infarction (non-STEMI), and unstable angina (UA).    

STEMI is the most severe form of ACS and represents a transmural infarction. ECG shows ST-elevation (more than 1 mm in contiguous leads), and cardiac enzymes are elevated. Once a diagnosis of STEMI is confirmed, urgent treatment should begin.  

In contrast, diagnostic ECG in the case of non-STEMI and UA does not have ST-elevation by definition. However, there are usually signs of ischemia on ECG (e.g., ST depression, T-wave inversion). Because both non-STEMI and UA are similar on ECG, cardiac troponins are used to differentiate between the two diagnoses. In non-STEMI, cardiac troponins are elevated, while in UA, cardiac troponins are normal.




Option Analysis

✅ Obtain a 12-lead ECG:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Obtain an emergent chest x-ray:
Incorrect: This patient is most likely experiencing acute coronary syndrome, and thus he needs a 12-lead ECG prior to any diagnostic imaging. 
❌ Obtain an echocardiogram  :
Incorrect: Echocardiogram is not part of the initial diagnostic evaluation in patients with suspected acute coronary syndrome – this patient needs an emergent 12-lead ECG. 
❌ Immediate admission of the patient for catheterization :
Incorrect: Patients with confirmed acute ST-elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI) should be immediately admitted to the catheterization laboratory for PCI. However, a twelve-lead ECG is needed to confirm the diagnosis prior to intervention.  
❌ Immediate administration of fibrinolytic agent :
Incorrect: Fibrinolytics are used in patients with acute ST-elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI) when PCI is not available; however, a twelve-lead ECG is needed to confirm the diagnosis prior to any intervention.

questions.text:
A 60-year-old man is brought to the emergency department because of crushing substernal chest pain for the past 45 minutes. The patient received 325 mg of aspirin in the ambulance. Medical history includes diabetes mellitus type 2 and asthma, for which the patient takes albuterol as needed. Other medications include carvedilol and sildenafil. The patient’s temperature is 36.8°C (98°F), pulse is 99/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 160/90 mm Hg. The patient appears diaphoretic. An ECG is obtained and shown below:  


Reproduced from: Wikimedia Commons  

Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
This patient with multiple cardiac risk factors (age, diabetes, and male sex) is now presenting with acute chest pain and diaphoresis, raising concerns for acute coronary syndrome. The ECG shows ST elevation in multiple leads, confirming the diagnosis of ST-elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI).   

Immediate restoration of myocardial blood flow is crucial to optimize myocardial muscle salvage and to reduce mortality. Primary percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI) is the gold standard and should be performed optimally within 90 minutes or less from first medical contact or up to 120 minutes for patients who are transported to a PCI-capable hospital. Other interventions during STEMI include oxygen, nitroglycerin, beta-blockers, statins, aspirin, P2Y12 inhibitors (e.g. ticagrelor), and heparin, while considering contraindications. Of note, this management is specific for STEMI; patients who present with unstable angina or non-ST-elevation myocardial infarction are managed differently.  

Option Analysis

❌ IV propranolol:
Incorrect: Beta blockers are an integral part of the acute therapy of STEMI as long as there are no contraindications, such as high risk for heart failure, hemodynamic compromise, bradycardia, or severe reactive airway disease. This patient has a history of asthma, therefore giving a non-selective beta-blocker is contraindicated, as it can cause bronchoconstriction. Beta 1-selective antagonists (e.g., metoprolol) may be considered.   
❌ IV tissue plasminogen activator (tPA)  :
Incorrect: Tissue plasminogen activator is a fibrinolytic drug that may be used if percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI) is unavailable within 120 minutes of first medical contact, if the symptoms have been present for less than 12 hours, and if there are no contraindications. This patient has been experiencing chest pain for 45 minutes, but in this case, PCI is available as an option and is therefore preferred.  
✅ Percutaneous coronary intervention:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Repeat ECG  :
Incorrect: A repeat ECG will not add any information to the case of this patient with an ST-elevation myocardial infarction. The patient requires urgent treatment to get the best outcomes. A repeat ECG is only required if the initial ECG is unequivocal.  
❌ Troponin T level:
Incorrect: Given the severe nature of his pain unrelieved by nitroglycerine and the ECG findings, the diagnosis is highly suggestive of ST-elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI). Troponin levels are useful in differentiating between acute coronary syndromes without ST elevation (non-STEMI vs. unstable angina), but here, there is no diagnostic ambiguity, given the aforementioned symptoms and ST elevation; he needs urgent treatment to salvage heart muscle.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man presents to the emergency department with severe, retrosternal chest pain and dyspnea. The pain started 3 hours ago and is increasing in intensity. Past medical history includes hypertension and diabetes. In addition, the patient had an epidural hemorrhage 2 months ago after hitting his head in a fall. In the emergency department, the patient is immediately stabilized and given aspirin. 12-lead ECG reveals ST-elevation in lead V1 to V4, and cardiac enzymes are ordered. The patient is given clopidogrel, atorvastatin, beta-blocker, and heparin. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient?

choices.text: Schedule the patient for a noninvasive cardiac stress testing
Admit the patient for immediate percutaneous intervention

questions.solution:
This patient has an acute ST-elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI), which is a subtype of acute coronary syndrome (ACS). The management of ACS begins with stabilizing the patient immediately upon presentation. Once the patient is stabilized, a 12-lead ECG and cardiac enzymes are obtained to reach a diagnosis and begin management accordingly.    

Patients with acute STEMI have a transmural infarction, which is due to complete occlusion of the coronary artery or its branches. Management of STEMI is time sensitive. Once the diagnosis is made, medical therapy is started with aspirin and clopidogrel, beta-blockers, nitrates, anticoagulation, and high-intensity statins. Simultaneously, it should be determined if the patient is a candidate for reperfusion therapy. Generally, patients who present within 12 hours of symptom onset are candidates for reperfusion therapy. The preferred method of reperfusion is percutaneous intervention (PCI) due to its high efficacy and lower side effect profile. However, if PCI is not available, fibrinolytic agents should be administered as soon as possible, unless contraindicated.  

The management of non-ST-elevation ACS (unstable angina and non-ST-elevation MI) differs from the management of STEMI. As with STEMI, medical therapy (e.g., aspirin, beta blockers, statins, anticoagulation) should begin immediately after the diagnosis; however, unless the patient has signs of ongoing ischemia (e.g., refractory angina, ventricular arrhythmias, hemodynamic instability, heart failure) immediate PCI is not indicated. Patients with non-ST-elevation ACS require further evaluation to determine the need for PCI.





Option Analysis

❌ Continue medical management :
Incorrect: This patient has an acute ST-elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI). As he is within the window period for percutaneous coronary intervention (e.g. PCI), reperfusion should be attempted immediately to preserve heart muscle and decrease mortality. Medical therapy alone in this patient is inappropriate. 
❌ Schedule percutaneous intervention within 24 hours:
Incorrect: Patients with acute STEMI should have reperfusion therapy (e.g. PCI) as soon as possible. Delaying PCI would be inappropriate.  
❌ Schedule the patient for a noninvasive cardiac stress testing:
Incorrect: Stress testing is contraindicated in STEMI.  
❌ Immediate administration of fibrinolytic agent:
Incorrect: This patient has a history of intracranial bleeding, which is an absolute contraindication for thrombolytic therapy. In addition, if PCI is available and the patient is within the time window for PCI, it is prefered over fibrinolytic therapy as it has better prognosis and fewer complications.  
✅ Admit the patient for immediate percutaneous intervention:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man comes to the office because of a throbbing headache and dizziness for the past few days. He visited the emergency department two months ago for sudden onset chest pain, which was adequately managed. The remainder of the review of systems is unremarkable. Past medical history is significant for type II diabetes mellitus and chronic angina. Current medications include metformin, atorvastatin, and isosorbide dinitrate. Family history is significant for myocardial infarction in his father. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 135/75 mmHg. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following strategies will most likely improve this patient’s symptoms?
questions.solution:
This patient’s headache and dizziness are most likely due to the development of nitrate tolerance, a significant problem in patients on chronic nitrate therapy.  

Isosorbide dinitrate is a nitrate used in the long-term prevention of angina pectoris. It acts by causing venous smooth muscle relaxation (via cGMP), leading to a decrease in cardiac preload, which, in turn, causes a reduction in myocardial oxygen demand. Continuous nitrate administration results in the development of tolerance (tachyphylaxis). Therefore, intermittent therapy with nitrate-free intervals (8-10 hours, usually timed during bed-time when cardiac work is minimum) must be provided to allow adequate time for the regeneration of reduced sulfhydryl groups (which helps restore vascular sensitivity to nitrates).  

The mechanism of nitrate tolerance is not well understood. Still, it is thought to result from decreased vascular sensitivity to nitrates and increased activity of the vasoconstrictor renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system (RAAS) in patients on chronic nitrate therapy. A similar effect is observed in industrial workers exposed to nitroglycerin (from explosives production) during the workweek, i.e. they develop tolerance to the vasodilation of nitrates after the initial period of headache and dizziness. The loss of tolerance over the weekend results in the recurrence of headache and dizziness upon re-exposure. This is called Monday disease.  



Option Analysis

❌ Discontinuation of metformin:
Incorrect: Headache and dizziness experienced by this patient are most likely due to the chronic consumption of nitrates. Metformin is known to cause GI side effects, including nausea and diarrhea occasionally. No drug-drug interaction has been reported among metformin, nitrates, or atorvastatin.   
✅ Intermittent therapy with nitrates:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Direct observed therapy:
Incorrect: Direct observed therapy (DOT) is usually recommended for healthcare workers to monitor the drug's dose and compliance with managing tuberculosis patients. There is no evidence of non-compliance in this patient.  
❌ Tapering off nitrates:
Incorrect: This patient suffers from chronic angina, and tapering off nitrates is not recommended.  
❌ Add-on therapy with PDE-5 inhibitors:
Incorrect: Add-on therapy with PDE-5 inhibitors will most likely exacerbate this patient’s headache and dizziness by potentiating the effect of cGMP (by inhibiting PDE-5).

questions.text:
A 57-year-old woman comes to the hospital for evaluation of intermittent episodes of chest pain that started four months ago. The patient reports that the chest pain is triggered by physical activity and improves with rest. Past medical history is notable for hypertension, type II diabetes mellitus, and hyperlipidemia. Temperature is 37.2°C (99.0°F), blood pressure is 150/75 mmHg, pulse is 67/min, and BMI is 29 kg/m2. Cardiac, pulmonary, and abdominal exams are non-contributory. An ECG is performed and shown below. The patient is started on a medication for her chest pain and is counseled on its side effects, which include constipation, facial flushing, and gingival hyperplasia. This medication works via which of the following mechanisms of action?


Image reproduced from Wikimedia Commons
questions.solution:
Calcium channel blockers (CCBs) are a class of vasodilators or medications that promote dilation of blood vessels. These medications are most commonly used to treat hypertension, supraventricular tachycardia, and angina pectoris (also called stable angina), pain caused by reduced blood flow to the heart muscle. Of note, this patient has chest pain that worsens with activity and improves with rest as well as a normal resting EKG, which is consistent with angina pectoris.    

As its name suggests, CCBs work by blocking voltage-gated calcium channels. This decreases the frequency with which calcium channels open, hence reducing calcium influx and intracellular calcium concentrations. In the sinoatrial node, CCBs are able to slow down cellular depolarization, which in turn decreases heart rate.    

Moreover, by reducing calcium influx, CCBs reduce calcium release from the sarcoplasmic reticulum, ultimately impairing muscle contractions. In the heart, this phenomenon causes decreased myocardial contractility as well as vasodilation of the coronary vessels.  

Ultimately, CCBs treat angina via two mechanisms: 1) decreasing the heart’s oxygen demand by reducing heart rate and contractility, and 2) increasing its oxygen supply via coronary artery vasodilation. Side effects of CCBs include peripheral edema, headaches, flushing, reflexive tachycardia, and gingival hyperplasia.  



Option Analysis

✅ Blockade of L-type calcium channels:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Stimulation of intracellular guanylyl cyclase:
Incorrect: Medications such as nitrates promote vasodilation via this mechanism. The activated guanylyl cyclases increase cGMP concentration, which in turn causes dephosphorylation of myosin light chains. As a result, light chains are unable to interact with actin and vasodilation occurs. While nitrates can be used to treat angina, they would not typically cause gingival hyperplasia
❌ Blockade of voltage-gated sodium channels:
Incorrect: This answer choice describes the mechanism of action of class I antiarrhythmic drugs (e.g., quinidine, lidocaine, propafenone). These medications can cause side effects ranging from thrombocytopenia to drug-induced lupus. However, class I antiarrhythmics are not used in the treatment of angina and would not cause the side effects described in the question stem.
❌  Inhibition of beta-adrenergic receptors:
Incorrect: Beta-blockers can be used to treat angina by decreasing heart rate and contractility, which in turn reduces myocardial oxygen demand. Side effects include bradycardia, bronchospasm, and fatigue. However, it would be atypical for beta-blockers to cause the side effects described in the question stem. 
❌ Inhibition of phosphodiesterase-5:
Incorrect: This answer choice describes the mechanism of action of PDE-5 inhibitors, such as sildenafil. PDE-5 inhibitors can treat erectile dysfunction, pulmonary hypertension, and benign prostatic hyperplasia. Side effects include headaches, flushing, and dyspepsia. However, PDE-5 inhibitors are not involved in the treatment of stable angina and would not cause gum hypertrophy.

questions.text: A 54-year-old woman visits the clinic for her annual health checkup. She states that she feels well at rest but has noticed chest discomfort with exertion. She denies dyspnea, orthopnea, cough, or syncope. Her medical history includes asthma and hypercholesterolemia. Her current medications include inhaled albuterol, inhaled corticosteroids, and atorvastatin. She has smoked a pack of cigarettes daily for 20 years and drinks 1-2 beers daily. She does not use recreational drugs. Her temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 23/min, blood pressure is 135/85 mmHg, and SpO<sub>2</sub> of 97%. BMI is 30 kg/m<sup>2</sup>. The cardiopulmonary examination is within normal limits. Resting ECG shows normal sinus rhythm without ST or T wave abnormalities. Exercise stress ECG shows ST depression of 1 mm in leads II, III, and avF with minimal exertion. She is initiated on aspirin, diltiazem, sublingual nitroglycerin tablets PRN, and counseled on smoking cessation. A coronary angiogram is scheduled for the next visit. Which of the following ECG changes can be expected given her new treatment regimen?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with symptoms and risk factors indicative of coronary artery disease. In the absence of resting ECG changes, noninvasive stress testing is the initial evaluation of choice. Cardiac stress testing that reveals ST depression with minimal exertion requires medical therapy and further evaluation with percutaneous coronary angiography.

Diltiazem is a potent coronary vasodilator that increases blood flow to vessels supplying normal and ischemic myocardium. In non-pacemaker tissue, class IV antiarrhythmics such as verapamil and diltiazem exert negative inotropic effects by inhibiting excitation-contraction coupling in the myocardium. This reduces the myocardial oxygen demand by acting as a negative inotrope, relieving angina.

The electrophysiological changes resulting from calcium channel blockade administration include prolongation of the effective refractory period of the AV node (pacemaker cardiomyocytes).
 

On an ECG, these electrophysiological changes manifest as a prolongation of the PR interval (>200ms). Thus the adverse effect of this medication includes AV block and sinus node depression. Consequently, medications like verapamil and diltiazem are contraindicated in patients with heart block and sick sinus syndrome.
 

Option Analysis

❌ Right axis deviation:
Incorrect: Right axis deviation is expected with conditions that involve right coronary pathology such as pulmonary hypertension, right ventricular hypertrophy, chronic lung disease, and pulmonary embolism. It is not anticipated with diltiazem administration.  
❌ QRS widening:
Incorrect: Wide QRS complexes often indicate a ventricular pathology and are commonly encountered in patients using a class Ia antiarrhythmic.  
❌ Inverted T waves:
Incorrect: Inverted T waves can be a benign variant or indicative of an underlying cardiovascular disease. Pathological causes of inverted t-waves include myocardial infarction, left ventricular strain patterns, and LBBB or RBBB.  
❌ Tall peaked T waves:
Incorrect: Tall peaked T waves can result from ischemic or non-ischemic insults to the myocardium. Ischemic etiologies include both the hyperacute and resolving phases of myocardial infarction, while nonischemic causes include hyperkalemia and left ventricular hypertrophy.  
✅ Prolongation of PR interval:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

A 45-year-old man comes to the office to establish care. He recently moved from out of state and has no acute symptoms. Past medical history is significant for type II diabetes mellitus diagnosed a year ago. He takes metformin daily. Family history is significant for myocardial infarction in the patient’s grandfather. The patient does not consume tobacco, alcohol, or illicit substances. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 135/85 mmHg. Physical examination is unremarkable. Laboratory testing reveals the findings below. The patient is started on a lipid-lowering drug to decrease the risk of cardiovascular mortality. Which of the following is the mechanism of action of the most appropriate lipid-lowering medication for this patient?  

Laboratory Value
Results
Glucose
115 mg/dL
Total cholesterol
220 mg/dL
Low-density lipoprotein (LDL)
150 mg/dL
High-density lipoprotein (HDL)
30 mg/dL
Hemoglobin A1c
5.9%

choices.text: Inhibition of cholesterol absorption at the intestinal brush border
Inhibition of bile acid reabsorption in the intestines
Activation of transcription regulators at peroxisome proliferator-activated receptors-Ɣ (PPAR-Ɣ)

questions.solution:
Lipid-lowering agents are an essential part of the management plan for any patient with a high risk of cardiovascular mortality. Assessing the 10-year atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease (ASCVD) risk in susceptible patients is helpful and can help guide lipid-lowering therapy. According to the guidelines, this patient should be started on a statin since it decreases the risk of cardiovascular mortality in patients aged 40-75 and with diabetes.

Statins (e.g., pravastatin, atorvastatin, rosuvastatin) are a class of medications that act by competitively inhibiting the enzyme HMG-CoA reductase, which helps convert HMG-CoA to mevalonate, a cholesterol precursor. Of note, this step is the rate-limiting reaction in cholesterol synthesis.

Statins lead to a decrease in hepatic cholesterol synthesis and increase in LDL recycling via upregulation of LDL receptors on hepatic cells. The LDL receptors not only increase the uptake of LDL-cholesterol but also increase the uptake of VLDLs (the major carrier of TG) to a smaller extent, resulting in a moderate decrease in TG levels. Furthermore, the liver increases its production of HDLs, which carry cholesterol back from the peripheral tissues to the liver.

The net effects include a significant reduction in LDL levels, a modest decrease in TG levels, and a modest increase in HDL levels.
 

Option Analysis

❌ Inhibition of cholesterol absorption at the intestinal brush border:
Incorrect: Ezetimibe inhibits cholesterol absorption at the intestinal brush border, thereby reducing liver cholesterol stores. Although it decreases serum LDL levels, it does not improve cardiovascular mortality and is associated with bothersome side effects (e.g. diarrhea). As a result, ezetimibe is not a preferred agent for this patient.  
✅ Inhibition of hydroxymethylglutaryl (HMG) CoA reductase:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Inhibition of bile acid reabsorption in the intestines:
Incorrect: Bile acid resins (e.g. cholestyramine) decrease LDL cholesterol by preventing bile acid reabsorption in the intestines. However, bile acid resins are not the first-line therapy for hypercholesterolemia and are also associated with numerous side effects (e.g., nausea, bloating, cramping, increased liver enzyme levels).  
❌ Activation of transcription regulators at peroxisome proliferator-activated receptors-Ɣ (PPAR-Ɣ):
Incorrect: Thiazolidinediones (e.g. pioglitazone) are a class of antidiabetic drugs that increases insulin sensitivity by activating the transcription regulator at PPAR-ɣ. This patient’s diabetes mellitus is adequately controlled by metformin and does not require the addition of another anti-diabetic drug. Moreover, glitazones are often associated with an increased risk of cardiovascular mortality.  
❌ Upregulation of lipoprotein lipase:
Incorrect: Fibrates activate PPAR-α, which causes upregulation of lipoprotein lipase levels and increases the clearance of serum triglycerides. This class of drugs also decreases very-low-density lipoproteins (VLDL) and induces HDL synthesis. However, fibrates have little to no effect on cardiovascular mortality.

questions.text:
A 68-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of retrosternal chest pain. The pain started 4 hours ago while playing soccer with his grandson. The pain radiates to his left arm and jaw and is not associated with breathing or positional change. Past medical history is significant for type II diabetes mellitus, hypertension, and erectile dysfunction. Current medications include insulin, enalapril, and sildenafil, and he reports taking all medications earlier this morning. He smokes a pack of cigarettes daily and drinks 3-4 beers on weekends. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 69/min, respirations are 18/min, blood pressure is 130/70 mm Hg, and SaO2 is 95% on pulse oximetry. An electrocardiogram is shown below. Administration of which of the following medications should be avoided in this patient?  


Reproduced from Wikimedia Commons
questions.solution:
This patient with acute onset retrosternal chest pain for 4 hours and ECG findings of ST-segment elevation in the anterior chest leads is most likely suffering from anterior wall acute myocardial infarction. Nitroglycerin is contraindicated in this patient due to its adverse interaction with sildenafil, a phosphodiesterase type 5 inhibitor (part of his current medication regimen) which can precipitate severe hypotension.  

The primary mechanism of action of nitrates involves decreasing cardiac preload by venodilation and a minor decrease in afterload by vasodilation of arterial beds. This is achieved by promoting the conversion of guanosine triphosphate (GTP) to cyclic guanosine monophosphate (cGMP), which causes smooth muscle relaxation via protein kinase G. Sildenafil, on the other hand, inhibits phosphodiesterase- 5, the enzyme necessary for the breakdown of cGMP. This results in the accumulation of cGMP, leading to excessive vasodilation and hypotension when used in combination with nitrates. If prescribed together, both drugs should be ingested at least 24-48 hours apart.  

Other contraindications to nitrates include bradycardia, right ventricular infarction (due to decreased preload), hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (due to increased outflow obstruction), and severe aortic stenosis. Common side effects include flushing, headache, orthostatic hypotension, and reflex tachycardia.  

Option Analysis

❌ Aspirin:
Incorrect: Aspirin is an anti-inflammatory drug administered in all patients with acute ST-elevation myocardial infarction. Its early administration is associated with decreased cardiovascular mortality rate and decreased incidence of re-infarction and stroke. It has no interaction with any drugs the patient is currently on.  
❌ Metoprolol:
Incorrect: Metoprolol, a β1-antagonist, is administered in nearly all patients with acute STEMI to relieve chest pain, reduce arrhythmias, and reduce cardiac workload (thereby preserving infarcted myocardial cells); contraindications of use include patients with a STEMI who also have symptoms of heart failure (elevated JVD, crackles on lung auscultation, audible S3). Contraindications of beta-blockers include heart failure, bradycardia, and reactive airway disease.  
❌ Enoxaparin:
Incorrect: Enoxaparin, low molecular weight heparin, is indicated in ACS to prevent intraluminal clot extension, formation, and re-infarction. It should be avoided in patients with contraindicated anticoagulants (history of cerebral aneurysm or arteriovenous malformation, intracranial neoplasm, recent thromboembolic stroke).  
❌ Morphine:
Incorrect: Morphine is indicated in ACS for persistent chest pain. It provides analgesia and lowers the adrenergic drive, reducing vascular resistance and afterload on the heart and reducing infarct size. It is not contraindicated in this patient.  
✅ Nitroglycerin:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 66-year-old man presents to the emergency department with crushing substernal chest pain. He is found to have an inferior wall myocardial infarction per ECG criteria, and the cardiac catheterization lab is activated. Before transferring, this patient is treated with aspirin and clopidogrel since the sum of their anti-platelet effects together is more significant than their individual effects. Which of the following best describes this type of pharmacodynamic medication interaction?
questions.solution:
Pharmacokinetic and pharmacodynamic medication interactions are the foundation for multiple medical treatments and adverse medication effects. An interaction between two or more drugs that causes the total effect of the drugs to be greater than the sum of the individual effects of each drug is referred to as synergism. Several significant interactions should be memorized for the USMLE and are outlined in the table above.    

Moreover, phase I metabolism of a drug, which is usually performed by the cytochrome P450 superfamily of mixed-function oxidases, can be affected by genetic and environmental factors. A common environmental influence is a drug-drug interaction in which a drug's induction or inhibition of a cytochrome enzyme alters the metabolism of another drug that is a substrate for that enzyme (e.g. warfarin).   

Option Analysis

✅ Synergistic:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Potentiation:
Incorrect: Potentiation is similar to synergism; however, a key difference is that one of the medications does not exert a therapeutic effect or has a completely different effect that enhances the principal medication.   
❌ Tachyphylactic :
Incorrect: Tachyphylactic refers to an acute decrease in response to a medication with repeated doses.   
❌ Permissive:
Incorrect: Permissive refers to the fact that for a medication to exert its full therapeutic effect, it must be in the presence of additional medication.   
❌ Antagonism:
Incorrect: Antagonism means that the effect of two substances together is less than the sum of their individual effects.

Family history is significant for type II diabetes mellitus and myocardial infarction in the patient’s father—review of systems is unremarkable. Vitals are within normal limits. Body mass index is 33 kg/m2. Physical examination is unremarkable. A lipid profile is obtained and the results are shown below. The patient is started on simvastatin. Which of the following best describes the effects of simvastatin on serum low-density lipoprotein, high-density lipoprotein, and triglyceride levels?

Statins competitively inhibit the enzyme HMG-CoA reductase, which normally converts HMG-CoA to mevalonate (a cholesterol precursor). In turn, there is a decrease in hepatic cholesterol synthesis and an increase in LDL recycling via the up-regulation of LDL receptors on hepatocytes. The LDL receptors not only increase the uptake of LDL-cholesterol but also increase the uptake of VLDLs (the major carrier of TG) to a smaller extent, resulting in a moderate decrease in triglyceride levels. Furthermore, the liver increases its production of HDLs, which carry cholesterol back from the peripheral tissues to the liver.

Such medications decrease the transport of free fatty acids to the liver and inhibit the activity of TG-synthesizing enzymes. They also slightly increase LDL levels.
